citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors).
citations.narrative:
The facility was providing a nutritional supplement and a joint supplement to the tigers, lions and singing dogs. The
manufacturer’s guidelines were not being followed for some of the animals and the veterinarian had not approved the
amounts given. Providing supplements at an amount that differs from the guidelines and that hasn’t been approved by the
attending veterinarian may lead to inadequate amounts given and potential health issues. The attending veterinarian must
be given appropriate authority to oversee all aspects of animal care including nutritional supplements.

Patrons can procure pellets from the admission’s office to feed the animals throughout the drive-through portion. The
facility has put in place several cameras instead of attendants in order to monitor the interactions. However, at the time of
inspection, the cameras from the entrance to the Giraffe barn as well as those from the camel enclosure to the end, were
not working. Public contact was not supervised in those areas. The facility representatives were able to pull up the
functioning cameras on their phones, but they did not have an employee monitoring the interactions through the cameras
at all times during periods of public contact. Without constant monitoring of the interactions, the safety of the animals and
the safety of the public cannot be assured. A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant
must be present at all times during periods of public contact.
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the
applicant.
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 10/27/2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection.
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.
n

narrative:
2.40(a)(2) 
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care (dealers and exhibitors). 
The facility was providing a nutritional supplement and a joint supplement to the tigers, lions and singing dogs. The 
manufacturer’s guidelines were not being followed for some of the animals and the veterinarian had not approved the 
amounts given. Providing supplements at an amount that differs from the guidelines and that hasn’t been approved by the 
attending veterinarian may lead to inadequate amounts given and potential health issues. The attending veterinarian must 
be given appropriate authority to oversee all aspects of animal care including nutritional supplements. 
2.131(d)(2) 
   
Handling of animals. 
Patrons can procure pellets from the admission’s office to feed the animals throughout the drive-through portion. The 
facility has put in place several cameras instead of attendants in order to monitor the interactions. However, at the time of 
inspection, the cameras from the entrance to the Giraffe barn as well as those from the camel enclosure to the end, were 
not working. Public contact was not supervised in those areas. The facility representatives were able to pull up the 
functioning cameras on their phones, but they did not have an employee monitoring the interactions through the cameras 
at all times during periods of public contact. Without constant monitoring of the interactions, the safety of the animals and 
the safety of the public cannot be assured. A responsible, knowledgeable, and readily identifiable employee or attendant 
must be present at all times during periods of public contact. 
 
This is a 1st Re-License Inspection for a Class “C” license. The inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the 
applicant. 
 
All items must be in compliance within 2 more inspections or by 10/27/2024 or the applicant will forfeit the license fee and 
must wait 6 months to reapply. Please contact your inspector to schedule your next Re-License Inspection. 
 
Regulated activity can continue under your existing USDA license until it expires.

n
